g.text: icting and heterogeneous results regarding the association between human
polymorphisms and alopecia areata (AA). This study aimed to review and quantitatively analyze the
In this study, all relevant publications were searched through December 2016. Odds ratios (ORs) and con
intervals (CIs) for comparisons between case and control groups were calculated. Stata 14.0 software was used to perform statistical
analysis. This research does not require formal ethical approval because the data used in this analysis do not involve personal
information and thus do not affect privacy.
respectively. Statistical evidence revealed no publication bias (
polymorphisms might decrease the AA risk.
Studies with adequate methodological quality on gene
environment interactions are needed to validate the results in
Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses.
, human leukocyte antigen, odds ratio, polymorphism, risk
Alopecia areata (AA) is a cell-mediated autoimmune disease
causing an unpredictable hair loss with no overt epidermal
changes. The lifetime risk of AA is estimated to be 1.7%. It
affects both sexes and people of all races, but is more
leads to round or oval patches, which may advance to all
scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or all body hair (alopecia
been discussed in many types of autoimmune diseases, for
As one of the autoimmune diseases which caused
by several major susceptibility genes, AA is genetically associated
with alleles of HLA in different ethnic groups.
lymphocytes play an important role in AA in
processes. They have been proposed to recognize the antigen
and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II complexes
on macrophages and Langerhans cells, and the expression may be
induced on other nucleated cells, leading to AA.
presenting the antigen to CD4+ T cells.

of Zhejiang Province, China (No. 2016ZA084), and the State Administration of
Traditional Chinese Medicine of the People
